articles.headline: Even a Wealthy Suburb Faces Pressure to Curb School Taxes
articles.snippet: Even in Bronxville, N.Y., where typical income is high, a look at the property tax trajectory has residents worried.
articles.abstract: Even in Bronxville, N.Y., where typical income is high, a look at the property tax trajectory has residents worried.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRONXVILLE, N.Y.  This wealthy New York suburb prides itself on its public schools. Class sizes are small. Students can choose from an array of subjects not offered everywhere. Teacher pay ranks among the nation’s highest. And voters long approved high real estate taxes to pay for it all.

articles.headline: Opposition in Libya Struggles to Form a United Front
articles.snippet: Rebels are facing a perhaps fatal obstacle: the need to forge a substitute to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in a state that he embodied.
articles.abstract: Rebels are facing a perhaps fatal obstacle: the need to forge a substitute to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in a state that he embodied.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — In less than three weeks, an inchoate opposition in Libya, one of the world’s most isolated countries, has cobbled together the semblance of a transitional government, fielded a ragtag rebel army and portrayed itself to the West and Libyans as an alternative to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s four decades of freakish rule.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Hollywood Feels Ripples From Libya
articles.snippet: Hollywood players and institutions were said to be scrambling to distance themselves from projects in which Saadi el-Qaddafi might be financially involved.
articles.abstract: Hollywood players and institutions were said to be scrambling to distance themselves from projects in which Saadi el-Qaddafi might be financially involved.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Things have gotten chilly here for Natural Selection, the film production company backed by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s son Saadi.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Chairwoman Under Fire Over Ethics Issues
articles.snippet: Mary L. Schapiro is facing Congressional questioning about a former general counsel who weighed in on the Bernard L. Madoff case even though he had a financial interest in it.
articles.abstract: Mary L. Schapiro is facing Congressional questioning about a former general counsel who weighed in on the Bernard L. Madoff case even though he had a financial interest in it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission took a beating two years ago for failing to detect Bernard L. Madoff’s multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme during the decades that he ran it.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: Flirting With a Repeat of a Stunted Recovery
articles.snippet: Positives and negatives in the economy are reminiscent of those from a year ago, when the recovery sputtered.
articles.abstract: Positives and negatives in the economy are reminiscent of those from a year ago, when the recovery sputtered.

articles.headline: Putting Afghan Plan Into Action Proves Difficult
articles.snippet: America’s political and military goals seem disconnected from the situation on the ground in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: America’s political and military goals seem disconnected from the situation on the ground in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALAM KHEL, Afghanistan  If the American-led fight against the Taliban was once a contest for influence in well-known and conventionally defined areas  the capital and large cities, main roads, the border with Pakistan, and a handful of prominent valleys and towns  today it has become something else.

articles.headline: For Lawmaker Examining Terror, a Pro-I.R.A. Past
articles.snippet: Representative Peter T. King, whose committee is holding hearings on the radicalization of American Muslims, once fervently supported a terrorist group, the Irish Republican Army.
articles.abstract: Representative Peter T. King, whose committee is holding hearings on the radicalization of American Muslims, once fervently supported a terrorist group, the Irish Republican Army.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For Representative Peter T. King, as he seizes the national spotlight this week with a hearing on the radicalization of American Muslims, it is the most awkward of résumé entries. Long before he became an outspoken voice in Congress about the threat from terrorism, he was a fervent supporter of a terrorist group, the Irish Republican Army.

articles.headline: U.S. Economy Is Better Prepared for Rising Gas Costs
articles.snippet: Because the last oil shock changed the behavior of consumers and businesses, economists doubt the price spike will end the rebound unless it gets much worse.
articles.abstract: Because the last oil shock changed the behavior of consumers and businesses, economists doubt the price spike will end the rebound unless it gets much worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: The increase in energy prices is beginning to resemble the rise in 2008. But this time, the American economy may be better prepared for higher fuel costs.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Bank Chief Rejects Idea of Reducing Home Loans
articles.snippet: Bank of America executives said on Tuesday that a government idea to write off tens of billions worth of mortgage debt was unworkable and warned that it would be unfair to untroubled borrowers.
articles.abstract: Bank of America executives said on Tuesday that a government idea to write off tens of billions worth of mortgage debt was unworkable and warned that it would be unfair to untroubled borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Showing resistance for the first time against government pressure to write off tens of billions worth of mortgage debt, Bank of America executives said on Tuesday that the idea was unworkable and warned that it would be unfair to borrowers who had managed to stay current on their loans.

articles.headline: Lobby Battle Over Loans for Lawsuits
articles.snippet: A legislative effort by companies providing the loans has been met with vigorous opposition from insurance companies and chambers of commerce.
articles.abstract: A legislative effort by companies providing the loans has been met with vigorous opposition from insurance companies and chambers of commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Companies that advance money to plaintiffs involved in personal injury lawsuits are campaigning in state capitals for legislation making clear that their growing industry is not subject to usury limits on interest rates or other state laws that protect borrowers.
